articles.headline: Authorities Shut Down Spam Ring
articles.snippet: An international spam network was ordered to shut down, stopping what the authorities say was one of the most prolific spam gangs on the Internet.
articles.abstract: An international spam network was ordered to shut down, stopping what the authorities say was one of the most prolific spam gangs on the Internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission won a preliminary legal victory against what it called one of the largest spam gangs on the Internet, persuading a federal court in Chicago on Tuesday to freeze the group’s assets and order the spam network to shut down.

articles.headline: Disappearing Credit Forces Hospitals to Delay Improvements
articles.snippet: The hospital industry is among those struggling with the credit scarcity that the federal government’s latest financial bailout plan is meant to alleviate.
articles.abstract: The hospital industry is among those struggling with the credit scarcity that the federal government’s latest financial bailout plan is meant to alleviate.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late August, even before the credit squeeze reached a full state of crisis, a hospital system in Hawaii filed for bankruptcy reorganization after a lender failed to extend a loan for another month.

articles.headline: A Winner for Treasury? Time Will Tell
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department’s profits — or losses — on its investments in banks under the bailout program depend on whether the banks return to health within a few years.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department’s profits — or losses — on its investments in banks under the bailout program depend on whether the banks return to health within a few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department will make substantial profits on its investments in banks under the bailout program announced Tuesday  if the banks return to health within a few years. If not, the government could end up breaking even, or perhaps even lose money.

articles.headline: Gadgetry Takes a Hit as Nervous Consumers Plan for Lean Holidays
articles.snippet: Demand for electronics is falling sharply — portending extra discounts for customers in coming months but a very unhappy holiday season for retailers.
articles.abstract: Demand for electronics is falling sharply — portending extra discounts for customers in coming months but a very unhappy holiday season for retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his retirement account devastated by the plunging stock market, Henry Vicenteno is feeling poor  poor enough to play the Grinch this holiday season.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Stephanie Rosenbloom

articles.headline: Next Victim of Turmoil May Be Your Salary
articles.snippet: The next stage of the downturn is likely to revolve around the worst slump in worker pay since the Great Depression.
articles.abstract: The next stage of the downturn is likely to revolve around the worst slump in worker pay since the Great Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is possible, for the first time in weeks, to imagine that the credit crisis may be about to ease. But one of the big lessons of the last year has been not to underestimate the severity of the economy’s problems. Those problems are not just about housing or Wall Street.

articles.headline: Banks’ Bailout Unlikely to Crimp Executive Pay
articles.snippet: The Treasury’s rescue plan will restrict pay packages for Wall Street executives, but experts say the provisions will have little real impact.
articles.abstract: The Treasury’s rescue plan will restrict pay packages for Wall Street executives, but experts say the provisions will have little real impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under the bailout plan for the nation’s banks unveiled on Tuesday, no heads will roll, as they did in the United Kingdom. No banking executives are likely to go hungry, either. But their parting may not be quite as sweet.

articles.headline: Courts Give Addicts a Chance to Straighten Out
articles.snippet: Drug courts have given addicts a chance to avoid prison by agreeing to oversight and addiction treatment.
articles.abstract: Drug courts have given addicts a chance to avoid prison by agreeing to oversight and addiction treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It was not your usual courtroom scene. For one thing, the judge choked up as he described one woman’s struggle with opiate addiction after her arrest for forging prescriptions.

articles.headline: From 2 Rivals, 2 Prescriptions
articles.snippet: The economic plans from John McCain and Barack Obama have provided voters with a clear choice on a big issue.
articles.abstract: The economic plans from John McCain and Barack Obama have provided voters with a clear choice on a big issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With Senator John McCain unveiling a $52.5 billion package of proposals on Tuesday, both presidential candidates have now outlined their plans for addressing the economic crisis, leaving voters with a clear choice when it comes to one of the biggest challenges the next president will face.

articles.headline: Poll Says McCain Is Hurting His Bid by Using Attacks
articles.snippet: If the election were held today, 53 percent of voters would vote for Barack Obama and 39 percent would vote for John McCain, according to a Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: If the election were held today, 53 percent of voters would vote for Barack Obama and 39 percent would vote for John McCain, according to a Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: The McCain campaign’s recent angry tone and sharply personal attacks on Senator Barack Obama appear to have backfired and tarnished Senator John McCain more than their intended target, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll has found.
articles.byline: By MICHAEL COOPER and MEGAN THEE

articles.headline: It’s 3 P.M. on Wall Street. The Hungry Bear Is on the Prowl.
articles.snippet: This time of the day has become Wall Street’s scariest hour, with stock market lurches and plunges, one of the worst bear markets in postwar history.
articles.abstract: This time of the day has become Wall Street’s scariest hour, with stock market lurches and plunges, one of the worst bear markets in postwar history.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has become the scariest hour on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Louise Story

articles.headline: Markets Suffer as Investors Weigh Relentless Trouble
articles.snippet: Investors are recognizing that the financial crisis is not the fundamental economic problem, and it has only amplified others.
articles.abstract: Investors are recognizing that the financial crisis is not the fundamental economic problem, and it has only amplified others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock markets plunged anew on Wednesday, nearly wiping out the record gains of Monday and sending another wave of wealth destruction washing over American households.
